bibl.title: Letter from H. McG. Robertson to Henry Rose Carter, December 5, 1924

div1.p: Robertson reports on cases of the plague on board ships.

div1.head: Letter from H. McG. Robertson to Henry Rose Carter, December 5, 1924
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
U. S. Marine Hospital
Chelsea Mass.
December 5, 24
Assistant Surgeon Genl
Henry R Carter, P. H. S.
Washington D. C.
My dear Doctor Carter:-
div1.p:
Your letter of the
29th of Nov was forwarded to me
at this hospital. I do not
know of any extensive outbreaks
of plague aboard ships;
but do recall numbers of
Vessels having been reported as
having one or two cases. I am
enclosing for your information
a memorandum which gives
reports of four Steamers
which had had from three
to four cases. In one instance
2
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
there was one pneumonic
case aboard. On page 2
of the memo. I mention the
case of a vessel arriving at
Lieth with, I think, about
6 cases of pneumonic plague
aboard. Am sorry I cant give
you an exact quotation
as to this, but am sure
some one in the Bureau library
will look this up for you
if you request it. It
would seem from these two
instances that pneumonic
plague need not spread
extensively on ship board.
3
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
In regard to fleas and
temperature I am afraid
the Bureau is not impressed
with the value of the work or
of any practical good that
might result from Such an
investigation. Some work
along this line was done
I believe here in Boston
and also in New York, but
it was done in a desultory
Sort of way end with, appar-
ently, little reference to my
suggestions as to temper-
ature relations. About a
year ago I wrote the Bureau
asking for a report of the
4
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
work done. I received a
reply that in 13 months a
certain number of fleas
had been counted, and that
they were of certain varieties,
giving percentages. This was of course not interesting
to me particularly, and I have heard
nothing further.

You may be interested
to know that this is the
first time I have been
in a hospital Since I
left you in Baltimore
on March 15, 1913! You
may imagine that I feel lost
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
I wonder what you
are doing along the plague
line. Don't you ever get
tired working?

I trust that you and
Miss Laura are well and
that your Christmas and
New Year may be very
happy. Please give Miss
Laura my kindest regards.
With best wishes, I am
